FeedItems.Title: Using Travis CI for GitHub Pages builds
FeedItems.Summary:
Short recap: GitHub Pages & Jekyll

This blog is powered by GitHub Pages, which uses Jekyll in the background. Jekyll is a static website generator, which means that this page is ‚Äúbuild‚Äù and has no server-side rendering logic when you hit the page - it‚Äôs pure static HTML, CSS and JS.

You could run Jekyll on your local box and publish the sites to GitHub Pages - I prefer a pure ‚ÄúGitHub Page‚Äù-based model. Actually I don‚Äôt even have Jekyll installed on my PC. I wrote a small blogpost about running Jekyll on Windows if you are interested.

Travis CI

As you might imaging - during the build stuff can break. In this case GitHub will send you a very short ‚Äúerror‚Äù email via mail. To get a more detailed report, GitHub suggests to use Travis CI, which is the main topic of this blogpost.

Travis CI Setup

The basic setup is pretty simple, but I had some issues - the last step is not very good documented - and that‚Äôs why I decided to blog about it.

1. Login to Travis CI and ‚Äúsync‚Äù your account

You will need to login to Travis CI with your GitHub account. This will kick in a ‚Äúsync‚Äù. After a short period you should see all your repositories on your profile page:

2. Enable the desired project on Travis CI

Just flip on the switch on your profil page for the desired project and Travis will watch the repository for any changes.

3. Adding a Gemfile and a .travis.yml file to your project

To build GitHub Page stuff via Travis you will need a Gemfile and a .tarvis.yml. My current files are pretty basic and a copy from the GitHub Pages Help site, with one important exception‚Ä¶

4. Targeting the correct branch

The last step is to ensure that Travis CI will search for the correct branch. In my case, I only have the ‚Äúgh-pages‚Äù branch, but Travis CI will look for a ‚Äúmaster‚Äù branch.

To configure Travis CI to use the correct ‚Äúgh-pages‚Äù branch you will need this config section inside the .yml:

branches:
 only:
 - gh-pages

After this setup you should already see the finished Travis CI build:

Important: The output of the build will not be copied over to GitHub - at this stage it is just a ‚Äúsafety net‚Äù. If you want to publish from Travis CI, there are many blogposts out there that describe this topic.

Hope this helps!
FeedItems.RawContent:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><item><guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.codeinside.eu/2016/03/03/using-travis-ci-for-github-page-builds</guid><link>https://blog.codeinside.eu/2016/03/03/using-travis-ci-for-github-page-builds/</link><title>Using Travis CI for GitHub Pages builds</title><description>
<p><img src="https://blog.codeinside.eu/assets/md-images/2016-03-03/travisci.png" alt="x" title="Travis CI Logo" /></p>

<h2 id="short-recap-github-pages--jekyll">Short recap: GitHub Pages &amp; Jekyll</h2>

<p>This blog is powered by <a href="https://pages.github.com/">GitHub Pages</a>, which uses <a href="https://jekyllrb.com/">Jekyll</a> in the background. Jekyll is a static website generator, which means that this page is ‚Äúbuild‚Äù and has no server-side rendering logic when you hit the page - it‚Äôs pure static HTML, CSS and JS.</p>

<p>You could run Jekyll on your local box and publish the sites to GitHub Pages - I prefer a pure ‚ÄúGitHub Page‚Äù-based model. Actually I don‚Äôt even have Jekyll installed on my PC. <a href="http://blog.codeinside.eu/2014/09/13/How-We-Moved-From-Wordpress-To-Jekyll-On-Windows/">I wrote a small blogpost about running Jekyll on Windows if you are interested</a>.</p>

<h2 id="travis-ci"><strong><a href="http://travis-ci.org">Travis CI</a></strong></h2>

<p>As you might imaging - during the build stuff can break. In this case GitHub will send you a very short ‚Äúerror‚Äù email via mail. To get a more detailed report, <a href="https://help.github.com/articles/viewing-jekyll-build-error-messages/">GitHub suggests to use Travis CI</a>, which is the main topic of this blogpost.</p>

<h2 id="travis-ci-setup">Travis CI Setup</h2>

<p>The basic setup is pretty simple, but I had some issues - the last step is not very good documented - and that‚Äôs why I decided to blog about it.</p>

<h3 id="1-login-to-travis-ci-and-sync-your-account">1. Login to Travis CI and ‚Äúsync‚Äù your account</h3>

<p>You will need to login to Travis CI with your GitHub account. This will kick in a ‚Äúsync‚Äù. After a short period you should see all your repositories on your profile page:</p>

<p><img src="https://blog.codeinside.eu/assets/md-images/2016-03-03/travisci-1.png" alt="x" title="Travis CI Profile Page" /></p>

<h3 id="2-enable-the-desired-project-on-travis-ci">2. Enable the desired project on Travis CI</h3>

<p>Just flip on the switch on your profil page for the desired project and Travis will watch the repository for any changes.</p>

<h3 id="3-adding-a-gemfile-and-a-travisyml-file-to-your-project">3. Adding a Gemfile and a .travis.yml file to your project</h3>

<p>To build GitHub Page stuff via Travis you will need a <a href="https://github.com/Code-Inside/Blog/blob/gh-pages/Gemfile">Gemfile</a> and a <a href="https://github.com/Code-Inside/Blog/blob/gh-pages/.travis.yml">.tarvis.yml</a>.
My current files are pretty basic and a copy from the GitHub Pages Help site, with <strong>one important exception</strong>‚Ä¶</p>

<h3 id="4-targeting-the-correct-branch">4. Targeting the correct branch</h3>

<p>The last step is to ensure that Travis CI will search for the correct branch. In my case, I only have the ‚Äúgh-pages‚Äù branch, but Travis CI will look for a ‚Äúmaster‚Äù branch.</p>

<p>To configure Travis CI to use the correct ‚Äúgh-pages‚Äù branch you will need this config section inside the .yml:</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>branches:
 only:
 - gh-pages  
</code></pre>
</div>

<p>After this setup you should already see the finished Travis CI build:</p>

<p><img src="https://blog.codeinside.eu/assets/md-images/2016-03-03/travisci-2.png" alt="x" title="Travis CI Build Page" /></p>

<p><strong>Important:</strong> The output of the build will not be copied over to GitHub - at this stage it is just a ‚Äúsafety net‚Äù. If you want to publish from Travis CI, there are many blogposts out there that describe this topic.</p>

<p>Hope this helps!</p>
</description><pubDate>Thu, 03 Mar 2016 23:30:00 Z</pubDate></item>

FeedItems.Title: Pretty Print XML in .NET
FeedItems.Summary:
Pretty Print

The term ‚Äúpretty print‚Äù describes that a document is more or less human readable formatted. So instead of this:

<Foo><Bar><Buzz></Buzz></Bar></Foo>

You might want to get this:

<Foo>
  <Bar>
    <Buzz></Buzz>
  </Bar>
</Foo>

Many editors support this feature - but we want to do it in code.

Pretty Print XML with .NET

The code is really simple, because XDocument does the heavy lifting for us.

var xDocument = XDocument.Parse(input);
string formattedXml = xDocument.ToString();

// Force XML Declaration if present
if (xDocument.Declaration != null)
{
  formattedXml = xDocument.Declaration + Environment.NewLine + formattedXml;
}
return formattedXml;

This should work in most cases - there might be some issues with comments or maybe special XML chars. If you have a better idea, please let me know.

Hope this helps!

</code></pre>
</div>

  &lt;Bar&gt;
    &lt;Buzz&gt;&lt;/Buzz&gt;
  &lt;/Bar&gt;
&lt;/Foo&gt;

</div>

<p>The code is really simple, because XDocument does the heavy lifting for us.</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>var xDocument = XDocument.Parse(input);
string formattedXml = xDocument.ToString();

// Force XML Declaration if present
if (xDocument.Declaration != null)
{
  formattedXml = xDocument.Declaration + Environment.NewLine + formattedXml;
}
return formattedXml;

</div>

<p>This should work in most cases - there might be some issues with comments or maybe special XML chars. If you have a better idea, please let me know.</p>

FeedItems.Title: ExpensiveMeeting - a Universal Windows Platform OSS app using Template10
FeedItems.Summary:
ExpensiveMeeting

The app - which is just a fun project and shouldn‚Äôt be taken too seriously - is like a stopwatch for meetings. But instead of the pure time it shows you also the burned money for your meeting, because time is money, right?

Don‚Äôt worry: The app is free and no ads are shown.

Windows Store Download

Behind the scenes: Universal Windows Platfrom (UWP)

The app itself is a UWP app, which means it runs on Windows 10, Windows IoT, Windows Mobile 10 (or is it Phone?) and maybe in the future on Xbox One. To see the app running on my phone, without touching the code at all, was pure fun. I really like the UWP approach.

Behind the scenes: Template10

Starting from scratch can be fun, but to shorten the development time I used the nice Template10 template, which gives me the typical hamburger app layout. The project can be found on GitHub and has a very active community.

Behind the scenes: All Code on GitHub

I decided to work in the open on GitHub, so if you are interested on the actual code, just take a look and do whatever you want to do.

If you have ideas or found bugs I would appreciate your help: Just create an issue or send a pull request.

FeedItems.Title: Shipping Visual C++ 2015 redistributable DLLs with your app or how to do an app-local deployment
FeedItems.Summary:
Small warning: I‚Äôm not a C++ dev

We use VC++ just for a very small part of our application, but this part needs the VC++ 2015 runtime ‚Äúinstalled‚Äù on the client, but we don‚Äôt want the UAC install dialog. So - let‚Äôs take a look how we can solve this problem.

And if I write something stupid here - please let me know.

Ways to deploy VC++ 2015

There are three ways to deploy the runtime:

  • Install it via the standalone VCRedist installer. This is probably the most known way, but requires elevated permissions because the file will be installed to System32.
  • Install it via a merge module. If you already have an installer, you can include the needed .msm files in your own installer, but this will also require elevated permissions because the files will be also installed to System32.
  • Deploy it with your app as app-local deployment. We will cover this in this blogpost, because we don‚Äôt want to touch anything that needs elevated permissions.

If you want to read more about the first two ways, the MSDN might be a good place to start.

App-Local deployment of the VC++ 2015 runtime

All what you need is already (if you are using Windows 10 & Visual Studio 2015) installed on your dev machine. Otherwise you will need to download the Windows 10 SDK and Visual Studio 2015.

Depending on your application, you will need to ship all dlls from the following folders with your application (= the dll/exe/whatever that needs the runtime) :

x86 applications

  • C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Redist\ucrt\DLLs\x86
  • C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\VC\redist\x86\Microsoft.VC140.CRT

x64 applications

  • C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Redist\ucrt\DLLs\x64
  • C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\VC\redist\x64\Microsoft.VC140.CRT

The ‚ÄúUniversal CRT‚Äù consists of many dlls and all are required. You have to copy them to your application folder and it should just work.

As far as I know, if a user has installed the runtime via VCRedist or the merge modules the files inside System32 will be picked.

I found this solution here and it seems to work just fine - no UAC prompt. Yay.

Hope this helps.
FeedItems.RawContent:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><item><guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.codeinside.eu/2016/02/23/ship-vcredist-2015-with-your-app-aka-applocal-deploy</guid><link>https://blog.codeinside.eu/2016/02/23/ship-vcredist-2015-with-your-app-aka-applocal-deploy/</link><title>Shipping Visual C++ 2015 redistributable DLLs with your app or how to do an app-local deployment</title><description>
<h2 id="small-warning-im-not-a-c-dev">Small warning: I‚Äôm not a C++ dev</h2>

<p>We use VC++ just for a very small part of our application, but this part needs the VC++ 2015 runtime ‚Äúinstalled‚Äù on the client, but we don‚Äôt want the UAC install dialog. 
So - let‚Äôs take a look how we can solve this problem.</p>

<p>And if I write something stupid here - please let me know.</p>

<h2 id="ways-to-deploy-vc-2015">Ways to deploy VC++ 2015</h2>

<p>There are three ways to deploy the runtime:</p>

<ul>
  <li>Install it via the standalone VCRedist installer. This is probably the most known way, but requires elevated permissions because the file will be installed to System32.</li>
  <li>Install it via a merge module. If you already have an installer, you can include the needed .msm files in your own installer, but this will also require elevated permissions because the files will be also installed to System32.</li>
  <li>Deploy it with your app as app-local deployment. We will cover this in this blogpost, because <strong>we don‚Äôt want to touch anything that needs elevated permissions</strong>.</li>
</ul>

<p>If you want to read more about the first two ways, the <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms235299.aspx">MSDN</a> might be a good place to start.</p>

<h2 id="app-local-deployment-of-the-vc-2015-runtime">App-Local deployment of the VC++ 2015 runtime</h2>

<p>All what you need is already (if you are using Windows 10 &amp; Visual Studio 2015) installed on your dev machine. Otherwise you will need to download the Windows 10 SDK and Visual Studio 2015.</p>

<p>Depending on your application, you will need to ship <strong>all</strong> dlls from the following folders with your application (= the dll/exe/whatever that needs the runtime) :</p>

<p><strong>x86 applications</strong></p>

<ul>
  <li>C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Redist\ucrt\DLLs\x86</li>
  <li>C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\VC\redist\x86\Microsoft.VC140.CRT</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>x64 applications</strong></p>

<ul>
  <li>C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Redist\ucrt\DLLs\x64</li>
  <li>C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\VC\redist\x64\Microsoft.VC140.CRT</li>
</ul>

<p>The <a href="https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/vcblog/2015/03/03/introducing-the-universal-crt/">‚ÄúUniversal CRT‚Äù</a> consists of many dlls and all are required. You have to copy them to your application folder and it should just work.</p>

<p>As far as I know, if a user has installed the runtime via VCRedist or the merge modules the files inside System32 will be picked.</p>

<p>I found this solution <a href="https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/sqlserver/en-US/d8f0acf9-5d4c-408d-8cea-c201fd61b9b7/local-deployment-of-redist-dlls-no-longer-works-with-visual-studio-2015?forum=visualstudiogeneral">here</a> and it seems to work just fine - no UAC prompt. Yay.</p>

<p>Hope this helps.</p>
</description><pubDate>Tue, 23 Feb 2016 22:45:00 Z</pubDate></item>

FeedItems.Title: Working with FontIcons in UWP
FeedItems.Summary:
FontIcons in UWP

Microsoft ships one builtin UWP (Universal Windows Platform) SymbolIcon class.

The good thing about such FontIcons is, that you can scale and change the appearances very nice and don‚Äôt need a bunch of image assets for your icons.

The down side is, that those icons are just a font‚Ä¶ so no multicolor option.

The builtin SymbolIcon usage is pretty easy:

<SymbolIcon Symbol="Accept" />

Using FontIcon to serve other font e.g. FontAwesome

Microsoft ships another simple class, the FontIcon class.

Including the font

You will need the actual Font-File, e.g. a .otf file. This file must be included in your project as Content.

After that the usage is pretty simple if you know the correct syntax:

<FontIcon FontFamily="./fontawesome.otf#FontAwesome" Glyph=""></FontIcon>

The Glyph-Property is the HexCode for the target char.

Pretty important, but I‚Äôm not a Font-Expert, so maybe this is ‚Äúnormal‚Äù

  • The #FontAwesome must be set.

  • In XAML the Glyph must be in this form

    ‚ÄúÔÇ≤‚Äù

  • From Code, the value must be unicode, e.g.

    Test.Glyph = ‚Äú\uf0b2‚Äù;

Instead of the ‚Äú./‚Ä¶‚Äù path syntax you could also use something like this:

<FontIcon FontFamily="ms-appx:///fontawesome.otf#FontAwesome" Glyph=""></FontIcon>

Result

The result is hopefully that you see the correct icon‚Ä¶ right?

BTW, we try to bring FontAwesome to UWP with a simple NuGet package.

And thanks to Alexander Witkowski for the suggestion of the FontIcon class - I didn‚Äôt know that this is part of the SDK.

Demo-Code

I made a pretty small UWP Demo, which can be viewed on our Samples-Repo.
FeedItems.RawContent:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><item><guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.codeinside.eu/2016/01/31/working-with-fonticons-in-uwp</guid><link>https://blog.codeinside.eu/2016/01/31/working-with-fonticons-in-uwp/</link><title>Working with FontIcons in UWP</title><description>
<h2 id="fonticons-in-uwp">FontIcons in UWP</h2>

<p>Microsoft ships one builtin UWP (Universal Windows Platform) <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/EN-US/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.symbol.aspx"><strong>SymbolIcon</strong></a> class.</p>

<p>The good thing about such FontIcons is, that you can scale and change the appearances very nice and don‚Äôt need a bunch of image assets for your icons.</p>

<p>The down side is, that those icons are just a font‚Ä¶ so no multicolor option.</p>

<p>The builtin SymbolIcon usage is pretty easy:</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>&lt;SymbolIcon Symbol="Accept" /&gt;
</code></pre>
</div>

<h2 id="using-fonticon-to-serve-other-font-eg-fontawesome">Using FontIcon to serve other font e.g. FontAwesome</h2>

<p>Microsoft ships another simple class, the <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.fonticon.glyph"><strong>FontIcon</strong></a> class.</p>

<h3 id="including-the-font">Including the font</h3>

<p>You will need the actual Font-File, e.g. a .otf file. This file must be included in your project as <strong>Content</strong>.</p>

<p>After that the usage is pretty simple if you know the correct syntax:</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>&lt;FontIcon FontFamily="./fontawesome.otf#FontAwesome" Glyph="&amp;#xf0b2;"&gt;&lt;/FontIcon&gt;
</code></pre>
</div>

<p>The Glyph-Property is the HexCode for the target char.</p>

<p>Pretty important, but I‚Äôm not a Font-Expert, so maybe this is ‚Äúnormal‚Äù</p>
<ul>
  <li>The #FontAwesome must be set.</li>
  <li>
    <p>In XAML the Glyph must be in this form</p>

    <p>‚ÄúÔÇ≤‚Äù</p>
  </li>
  <li>
    <p>From Code, the value must be unicode, e.g.</p>

    <p>Test.Glyph = ‚Äú\uf0b2‚Äù;</p>
  </li>
</ul>

<p>Instead of the ‚Äú./‚Ä¶‚Äù path syntax you could also use something like this:</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>&lt;FontIcon FontFamily="ms-appx:///fontawesome.otf#FontAwesome" Glyph="&amp;#xf0b2;"&gt;&lt;/FontIcon&gt;
</code></pre>
</div>

<h2 id="result">Result</h2>

<p>The result is hopefully that you see the correct icon‚Ä¶ right?</p>

<p>BTW, we try to bring <a href="https://github.com/charri/Font-Awesome-WPF/issues/23">FontAwesome to UWP</a> with a simple NuGet package.</p>

<p>And thanks to <a href="https://twitter.com/Alex_Witkowski/status/692134058051178502">Alexander Witkowski</a> for the suggestion of the FontIcon class - I didn‚Äôt know that this is part of the SDK.</p>

<h2 id="demo-code">Demo-Code</h2>

<p>I made a pretty small UWP Demo, which can be viewed on our <a href="https://github.com/Code-Inside/Samples/tree/master/2016/FontAwesomeDemo">Samples-Repo</a>.</p>
</description><pubDate>Sun, 31 Jan 2016 20:30:00 Z</pubDate></item>

FeedItems.Title: Serving embedded resources with ASP.NET WebApi
FeedItems.Summary:
Embedded files? Why?

In a normal Web-Application all files are somehow stored as files in the app directory, but sometimes it could be handy to embed those files.

One scenario could be that you have a ‚Äúlibrary‚Äù, which can be integrated in a larger application. If you don‚Äôt want to pull over all files and you just want to expose a single assembly (for example as NuGet package) embedded resources might come handy.

Demo-Application

My demo application is a simple ConsoleApp, which a selfhosting WebAPI and two Controllers (Demo and Pages):

Important is, that my ‚Äútarget‚Äù html and css file are marked as Embedded Resource.

Routing

In my sample I have created on ‚ÄúPageController‚Äù, which accepts all requests that seems to target the embedded files.

Registration:

public class Startup
{
    public void Configuration(IAppBuilder appBuilder)
    {
        HttpConfiguration config = new HttpConfiguration();

        config.MapHttpAttributeRoutes();

        config.Routes.MapHttpRoute(
            name: "ApiV1",
            routeTemplate: "api/v1/{controller}/{id}",
            defaults: new { id = RouteParameter.Optional }
            );

        config.Routes.MapHttpRoute(
           name: "PageController",
           routeTemplate: "{*anything}",
           defaults: new { controller = "Page", uri = RouteParameter.Optional });

        appBuilder.UseWebApi(config);
    }

}

The ‚ÄúPageController‚Äù

This controller will try to read the HTTP GET PathAndQuery and will look inside the assembly resources for something with the same name.

public class PageController : ApiController
{
    private const string ResourcePath = "SelfHostWithBetterRouting.Pages{0}";

    public static string GetStreamContent(string folderAndFileInProjectPath)
    {
        var asm = Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly();
        var resource = string.Format(ResourcePath, folderAndFileInProjectPath);

        using (var stream = asm.GetManifestResourceStream(resource))
        {
            if (stream != null)
            {
                var reader = new StreamReader(stream);
                return reader.ReadToEnd();
            }
        }
        return String.Empty;
    }


    public HttpResponseMessage Get()
    {
        var virtualPathRoot = this.Request.GetRequestContext().VirtualPathRoot;
        string filename = this.Request.RequestUri.PathAndQuery;

        // remove SERVER/appname from request to get the relative filename
        if (virtualPathRoot != "/")
        {
            filename = filename.ToLowerInvariant().Replace(virtualPathRoot.ToLowerInvariant(), string.Empty);
        }
        
        // input as /page-assets/js/scripts.js
        if (filename == "/" || filename == "")
        {
            filename = ".index.html";
        }

        // folders will be seen as "namespaces" - so replace / with the .
        filename = filename.Replace("/", ".");
        // resources can't be named with -, so it will be replaced with a _
        filename = filename.Replace("-", "_");

        var mimeType = System.Web.MimeMapping.GetMimeMapping(filename);

        var fileStreamContent = GetStreamContent(filename);

        if (string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(fileStreamContent))
        {
            throw new Exception(string.Format("Can't find embedded file for '{0}'", filename));
        }

        if (virtualPathRoot != "/")
        {
            fileStreamContent = fileStreamContent.Replace("~/", virtualPathRoot + "/");
        }
        else
        {
            fileStreamContent = fileStreamContent.Replace("~/", virtualPathRoot);
        }

        var response = new HttpResponseMessage();
        response.Content = new StringContent(fileStreamContent);
        response.Content.Headers.ContentType = new MediaTypeHeaderValue(mimeType);
        return response;
    }

}

Mix the ‚ÄúPageController‚Äù and normal WebAPI Controllers

In my sample the ‚ÄúPageController‚Äù will catch all requests that are not handled by other controllers, so you could even serve a general 404 page.

Hosting in IIS

If you host this inside an IIS it will not work out of the box, because the IIS itself tries to serve static content. One easy option would be to include this inside your web.config:

<!-- prevent IIS from serving embeddded stuff -->
<location path="pages">
    <system.webServer>
        <handlers>
            <add name="nostaticfile" path="*" verb="GET" type="System.Web.Handlers.TransferRequestHandler" preCondition="integratedMode,runtimeVersionv4.0" />
        </handlers>
    </system.webServer>
</location>

With this web.config setting in place the request should route through your code.

Result

The self hosting WebAPI returns the ‚Äúindex.html‚Äù and the linked ‚Äúsite.css‚Äù - all embedded inside the assembly:

In an older blogpost I used a similar approach, but the routing part is now ‚Äúbetter‚Äù solved.

Hope this helps!

The code is also available on GitHub.

{

    {

        using (var stream = asm.GetManifestResourceStream(resource))
        {

            {

    }


    public HttpResponseMessage Get()
    {
        var virtualPathRoot = this.Request.GetRequestContext().VirtualPathRoot;

            filename = filename.ToLowerInvariant().Replace(virtualPathRoot.ToLowerInvariant(), string.Empty);
        }
        
        // input as /page-assets/js/scripts.js
        if (filename == "/" || filename == "")
        {
            filename = ".index.html";
        }

        // folders will be seen as "namespaces" - so replace / with the .
        filename = filename.Replace("/", ".");
        // resources can't be named with -, so it will be replaced with a _
        filename = filename.Replace("-", "_");

        var mimeType = System.Web.MimeMapping.GetMimeMapping(filename);

        }

        if (virtualPathRoot != "/")
        {
            fileStreamContent = fileStreamContent.Replace("~/", virtualPathRoot + "/");
        }
        else
        {
            fileStreamContent = fileStreamContent.Replace("~/", virtualPathRoot);
        }

        var response = new HttpResponseMessage();
        response.Content = new StringContent(fileStreamContent);
        response.Content.Headers.ContentType = new MediaTypeHeaderValue(mimeType);
        return response;
    }

}	
</code></pre>
</div>

<h2 id="mix-the-pagecontroller-and-normal-webapi-controllers">Mix the ‚ÄúPageController‚Äù and normal WebAPI Controllers</h2>

<p>In my sample the ‚ÄúPageController‚Äù will catch all requests that are not handled by other controllers, so you could even serve a general 404 page.</p>

<h2 id="hosting-in-iis">Hosting in IIS</h2>

<p>If you host this inside an IIS it will not work out of the box, because the IIS itself tries to serve static content. One easy option would be to include this inside your web.config:</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>&lt;!-- prevent IIS from serving embeddded stuff --&gt;

    &lt;system.webServer&gt;

            &lt;add name="nostaticfile" path="*" verb="GET" type="System.Web.Handlers.TransferRequestHandler" preCondition="integratedMode,runtimeVersionv4.0" /&gt;
        &lt;/handlers&gt;

&lt;/location&gt;
</code></pre>
</div>

<p>With this web.config setting in place the request should route through your code.</p>

<h2 id="result">Result</h2>

<p>The self hosting WebAPI returns the ‚Äúindex.html‚Äù and the linked ‚Äúsite.css‚Äù - all embedded inside the assembly:</p>

FeedItems.Title: Working with JumpLists in WPF Apps
FeedItems.Summary:
JumpLists?

JumpLists were introduced with Windows 7 and if it they are implemented right are pretty handy, because it can provide common functionality.

A real world example:

JumpLists with .NET

In pre .NET 4.0 times there was a Windows7API Code Pack available to access the JumpLists APIs of Windows and many older blogposts reference it, but since .NET 4.0 is out the JumpList APIs are part of the PresentationFramework.dll. So, you don‚Äôt need any other library - at least not for the stuff that I want to show you here.

JumpLists & Windows Vista

A warning for everyone that still have to support Windows Vista: .NET 4.0 is supported on Windows Vista, but the JumpLists were introduced with Windows 7. If you are trying to create a JumpList or touch the JumpList APIs your app will crash with a NotSupportedException.

Creating JumpLists via XAML

Small warning: If you try this on Windows Vista, your app will just crash‚Ä¶

JumpLists are registred per application and the easiest way to create a (static) JumpList is via XAML in the App.xaml:

<Application x:Class="Jumplist_Sample.App"
            xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation"
            xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
            StartupUri="MainWindow.xaml">
    <Application.Resources>
        
    </Application.Resources>
    <JumpList.JumpList>
        <JumpList ShowRecentCategory="True"
                ShowFrequentCategory="True"
                
                JumpItemsRejected="JumpList_JumpItemsRejected"
                JumpItemsRemovedByUser="JumpList_JumpItemsRemovedByUser">
            
            <JumpTask Title="Notepad" 
                    Description="Open Notepad." 
                    ApplicationPath="C:\Windows\notepad.exe"
                    IconResourcePath="C:\Windows\notepad.exe"/>
            <JumpTask Title="Read Me" 
                    Description="Open readme.txt in Notepad." 
                    ApplicationPath="C:\Windows\notepad.exe"
                    IconResourcePath="C:\Windows\System32\imageres.dll"
                    IconResourceIndex="14"
                    WorkingDirectory="C:\Users\Public\Documents"
                    Arguments="readme.txt"/>
        </JumpList>
    </JumpList.JumpList>
</Application>

Creating JumpLists via Code

The ‚Äúcoding‚Äù JumpList API is a bit odd to use, but still easy to understand:

var jt = new JumpTask
{
    ApplicationPath = "C:\\Windows\\notepad.exe",
    Arguments = "readme.txt",
    Title = "Recent Entry for Notepad",
    CustomCategory = "Dummy"
};

JumpList.AddToRecentCategory(jt);



var jt2 = new JumpTask
{
    ApplicationPath = "C:\\Windows\\notepad.exe",
    Arguments = "readme.txt",
    Title = "Code Entry for Notepad",
    CustomCategory = "Dummy"
};

var currentJumplist = JumpList.GetJumpList(App.Current);
currentJumplist.JumpItems.Add(jt2);
currentJumplist.Apply();

The ‚ÄúApply()‚Äù call is needed, otherwise the new JumpItem will not be added. As you can see, you can create new JumpList entries, add (and I think you could also remove items) from the default recent category. Besides JumpTasks there is JumpPath, which just contains a link.

In the XAML Part I also hooked up some events, so your application can get notified when a user pins something or removes something which you might want to handle.

Result

Oh‚Ä¶ and of course: Windows 10 still supports JumpLists and there are rumors that even UWP apps will somehow support JumpLists.

A good read was this blogpost (and it also contains information about other Windows 7 ‚ÄúTaskbar‚Äù-enhancements which are still valid for Windows 10).

Hope this helps!

The code is also available on GitHub.
FeedItems.RawContent:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><item><guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.codeinside.eu/2015/11/30/working-with-jumplists-in-wpf-apps</guid><link>https://blog.codeinside.eu/2015/11/30/working-with-jumplists-in-wpf-apps/</link><title>Working with JumpLists in WPF Apps</title><description>
<h2 id="jumplists">JumpLists?</h2>

<p>JumpLists were introduced with Windows 7 and if it they are implemented right are pretty handy, because it can provide common functionality.</p>

<p>A real world example:</p>

<p><img src="https://blog.codeinside.eu/assets/md-images/2015-11-30/jumplistdemo.png" alt="x" title="JumpList Demo" /></p>

<h2 id="jumplists-with-net">JumpLists with .NET</h2>

<p>In pre .NET 4.0 times there was a Windows7API Code Pack available to access the JumpLists APIs of Windows and many older blogposts reference it, but since .NET 4.0 is out the JumpList APIs are part of the <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.windows.shell.jumpitem(v=vs.110).aspx">PresentationFramework.dll</a>. 
So, you don‚Äôt need any other library - at least not for the stuff that I want to show you here.</p>

<h2 id="jumplists--windows-vista">JumpLists &amp; Windows Vista</h2>

<p>A warning for everyone that still have to support Windows Vista: .NET 4.0 is supported on Windows Vista, but the JumpLists were introduced with Windows 7.
If you are trying to create a JumpList or touch the JumpList APIs your app will crash with a NotSupportedException.</p>

<h2 id="creating-jumplists-via-xaml">Creating JumpLists via XAML</h2>

<p><strong>Small warning: If you try this on Windows Vista, your app will just crash‚Ä¶</strong></p>

<p>JumpLists are registred per application and the easiest way to create a (static) JumpList is via XAML in the App.xaml:</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>&lt;Application x:Class="Jumplist_Sample.App"
            xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation"
            xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
            StartupUri="MainWindow.xaml"&gt;
    &lt;Application.Resources&gt;
        
    &lt;/Application.Resources&gt;
    &lt;JumpList.JumpList&gt;
        &lt;JumpList ShowRecentCategory="True"
                ShowFrequentCategory="True"
                
                JumpItemsRejected="JumpList_JumpItemsRejected"
                JumpItemsRemovedByUser="JumpList_JumpItemsRemovedByUser"&gt;
            
            &lt;JumpTask Title="Notepad" 
                    Description="Open Notepad." 
                    ApplicationPath="C:\Windows\notepad.exe"
                    IconResourcePath="C:\Windows\notepad.exe"/&gt;
            &lt;JumpTask Title="Read Me" 
                    Description="Open readme.txt in Notepad." 
                    ApplicationPath="C:\Windows\notepad.exe"
                    IconResourcePath="C:\Windows\System32\imageres.dll"
                    IconResourceIndex="14"
                    WorkingDirectory="C:\Users\Public\Documents"
                    Arguments="readme.txt"/&gt;
        &lt;/JumpList&gt;
    &lt;/JumpList.JumpList&gt;
&lt;/Application&gt;
</code></pre>
</div>

<h2 id="creating-jumplists-via-code">Creating JumpLists via Code</h2>

<p>The ‚Äúcoding‚Äù JumpList API is a bit odd to use, but still easy to understand:</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>var jt = new JumpTask
{
    ApplicationPath = "C:\\Windows\\notepad.exe",
    Arguments = "readme.txt",
    Title = "Recent Entry for Notepad",
    CustomCategory = "Dummy"
};

JumpList.AddToRecentCategory(jt);



var jt2 = new JumpTask
{
    ApplicationPath = "C:\\Windows\\notepad.exe",
    Arguments = "readme.txt",
    Title = "Code Entry for Notepad",
    CustomCategory = "Dummy"
};

var currentJumplist = JumpList.GetJumpList(App.Current);
currentJumplist.JumpItems.Add(jt2);
currentJumplist.Apply();
</code></pre>
</div>

<p>The ‚ÄúApply()‚Äù call is needed, otherwise the new JumpItem will not be added. As you can see, you can create new JumpList entries, add (and I think you could also remove items) from the default recent category.
Besides <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.windows.shell.jumptask(v=vs.110).aspx">JumpTasks</a> there is <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.windows.shell.jumppath(v=vs.110).aspx">JumpPath</a>, which just contains a link.</p>

<p>In the XAML Part I also hooked up some events, so your application can get notified when a user pins something or removes something which you might want to handle.</p>

<h2 id="result">Result</h2>

<p><img src="https://blog.codeinside.eu/assets/md-images/2015-11-30/jumplistresult.png" alt="x" title="Result of Democode" /></p>

<p>Oh‚Ä¶ and of course: Windows 10 still supports JumpLists and there are rumors that even UWP apps will somehow support JumpLists.</p>

<p>A good read was <a href="http://elegantcode.com/2011/01/21/wpf-windows-7-taskbar-part-two-jump-lists/">this blogpost</a> (and it also contains information about other Windows 7 ‚ÄúTaskbar‚Äù-enhancements which are still valid for Windows 10).</p>

<p>Hope this helps!</p>

<p>The code is also available on <strong><a href="https://github.com/Code-Inside/Samples/tree/master/2015/Jumplists">GitHub</a></strong>.</p>
</description><pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov 2015 23:30:00 Z</pubDate></item>

FeedItems.Title: XML deserialize to abstract class, interface or base class
FeedItems.Summary:
Let‚Äôs assume we have the following XML structure:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
<Root>
  <Node>
    <Label Id="Label1">Betreff</Label>
    <TextBox Id="TextBox1" MultiLines="3" />
  </Node>
  <Node>
    <Label Id="Label2">Betreff 123132</Label>
    <TextBox Id="TextBox2" />
    <Button Id="Button1" Label="Hello World" Action="Foobar" />
  </Node>
</Root>

Under we have n--elements and each element has a couple of specialized elements. The elements share a common attribute, in this case "Id", so we could say that we need a "Base"-Element.

Code: Deserialize the elements & co.

The first step: We need to deserialize the and it's children.

public class Root
{
    [XmlElement(ElementName = "Node")]
    public List<Node> Nodes { get; set; }
}

Next - and this is the main part of this blogpost - we need to describe the element and that it contains a list of "baseelements".

public class Node
{
    [XmlElement(typeof(LabelElement), ElementName = "Label")]
    [XmlElement(typeof(TextBoxElement), ElementName = "TextBox")]
    [XmlElement(typeof(ButtonElement), ElementName = "Button")]
    public List<BaseElement> Elements { get; set; }
}

As you can see, we need to ‚Äúregister‚Äù each specialized known element. The default XmlSerializer will read all XmlElement Attributes and will do the main work.

The last part: The base class and the specialized classes for each element.

public abstract class BaseElement
{
    [XmlAttribute(AttributeName = "Id")]
    public string Id { get; set; }
}

public class ButtonElement : BaseElement
{
    [XmlAttribute(AttributeName = "Label")]
    public string Label { get; set; }

    [XmlAttribute(AttributeName = "Action")]
    public string Action { get; set; }
}

public class LabelElement : BaseElement
{
    [XmlText]
    public string Content { get; set; }
}

public class TextBoxElement : BaseElement
{
    [XmlAttribute(AttributeName = "MultiLines")]
    public int MultiLines { get; set; }
}

Interfaces, base classes etc.

It doesn‚Äôt matter if you choose a interface, base class or a abstract base class. The built-in XmlSerializer is flexible, but as far as I know you will need to ‚Äúregister‚Äù the implementation elements on the base element. So there is no ‚Äúconvention‚Äù or any magic in place.

Using the code

Using the XmlSerializer is simple:

FileStream readFileStream = new FileStream(@"test.xml", FileMode.Open, FileAccess.Read, FileShare.Read);

XmlSerializer serializer = new XmlSerializer(typeof(Root));
var test = serializer.Deserialize(readFileStream);

Serializing

If you want to serialize objects to XML with this code the XmlSerializer should be well prepared and no code changes should be needed. It just works ;)

Hope this helps!

The code is also available on GitHub.
FeedItems.RawContent:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><item><guid isPermaLink="false">https://blog.codeinside.eu/2015/10/25/xml-deserialize-to-abstract-class-interface-or-base-class</guid><link>https://blog.codeinside.eu/2015/10/25/xml-deserialize-to-abstract-class-interface-or-base-class/</link><title>XML deserialize to abstract class, interface or base class</title><description>
<p>Let‚Äôs assume we have the following XML structure:</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code><span class="cp">&lt;?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?&gt;</span>
<span class="nt">&lt;Root&gt;</span>
  <span class="nt">&lt;Node&gt;</span>
    <span class="nt">&lt;Label</span> <span class="na">Id=</span><span class="s">"Label1"</span><span class="nt">&gt;</span>Betreff<span class="nt">&lt;/Label&gt;</span>
    <span class="nt">&lt;TextBox</span> <span class="na">Id=</span><span class="s">"TextBox1"</span> <span class="na">MultiLines=</span><span class="s">"3"</span> <span class="nt">/&gt;</span>
  <span class="nt">&lt;/Node&gt;</span>
  <span class="nt">&lt;Node&gt;</span>
    <span class="nt">&lt;Label</span> <span class="na">Id=</span><span class="s">"Label2"</span><span class="nt">&gt;</span>Betreff 123132<span class="nt">&lt;/Label&gt;</span>
    <span class="nt">&lt;TextBox</span> <span class="na">Id=</span><span class="s">"TextBox2"</span> <span class="nt">/&gt;</span>
    <span class="nt">&lt;Button</span> <span class="na">Id=</span><span class="s">"Button1"</span> <span class="na">Label=</span><span class="s">"Hello World"</span> <span class="na">Action=</span><span class="s">"Foobar"</span> <span class="nt">/&gt;</span>
  <span class="nt">&lt;/Node&gt;</span>
<span class="nt">&lt;/Root&gt;</span>
</code></pre>
</div>

<p>Under <Root> we have n-<Node>-elements and each <Node> element has a couple of specialized elements. The elements share a common attribute, in this case "Id", so we could say that we need a "Base"-Element.</Node></Node></Root></p>

<h2 id="code-deserialize-the-elements--co">Code: Deserialize the elements &amp; co.</h2>

<p>The first step: We need to deserialize the <Root> and it's <Node> children.</Node></Root></p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>public class Root
{
    [XmlElement(ElementName = "Node")]
    public List&lt;Node&gt; Nodes { get; set; }
}
</code></pre>
</div>

<p>Next - and this is the <strong>main part of this blogpost</strong> - we need to describe the <Node> element and that it contains a list of "baseelements".</Node></p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>public class Node
{
    [XmlElement(typeof(LabelElement), ElementName = "Label")]
    [XmlElement(typeof(TextBoxElement), ElementName = "TextBox")]
    [XmlElement(typeof(ButtonElement), ElementName = "Button")]
    public List&lt;BaseElement&gt; Elements { get; set; }
}
</code></pre>
</div>

<p>As you can see, we need to ‚Äúregister‚Äù each specialized known element. The default XmlSerializer will read all XmlElement Attributes and will do the main work.</p>

<p>The last part: The base class and the specialized classes for each element.</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>public abstract class BaseElement
{
    [XmlAttribute(AttributeName = "Id")]
    public string Id { get; set; }
}

public class ButtonElement : BaseElement
{
    [XmlAttribute(AttributeName = "Label")]
    public string Label { get; set; }

    [XmlAttribute(AttributeName = "Action")]
    public string Action { get; set; }
}

public class LabelElement : BaseElement
{
    [XmlText]
    public string Content { get; set; }
}

public class TextBoxElement : BaseElement
{
    [XmlAttribute(AttributeName = "MultiLines")]
    public int MultiLines { get; set; }
}
</code></pre>
</div>

<h2 id="interfaces-base-classes-etc">Interfaces, base classes etc.</h2>

<p>It doesn‚Äôt matter if you choose a interface, base class or a abstract base class. The built-in XmlSerializer is flexible, but as far as I know you will need to ‚Äúregister‚Äù the implementation elements on the base element. So there is no ‚Äúconvention‚Äù or any magic in place.</p>

<h2 id="using-the-code">Using the code</h2>

<p>Using the XmlSerializer is simple:</p>

<div class="highlighter-rouge"><pre class="highlight"><code>FileStream readFileStream = new FileStream(@"test.xml", FileMode.Open, FileAccess.Read, FileShare.Read);

XmlSerializer serializer = new XmlSerializer(typeof(Root));
var test = serializer.Deserialize(readFileStream);
</code></pre>
</div>

<p><img src="https://blog.codeinside.eu/assets/md-images/2015-10-25/result.PNG" alt="x" title="Xml Deserializer" /></p>

<h2 id="serializing">Serializing</h2>

<p>If you want to serialize objects to XML with this code the XmlSerializer should be well prepared and no code changes should be needed. It just works ;)</p>

<p>Hope this helps!</p>

<p>The code is also available on <strong><a href="https://github.com/Code-Inside/Samples/tree/master/2015/XmlBaseClassDeserializer">GitHub</a></strong>.</p>
</description><pubDate>Sun, 25 Oct 2015 22:00:00 Z</pubDate></item>

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Large authorizationDataIdToken (because of roles etc.) & cookie storage" (#56) at damienbod/angular-auth-oidc-client
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi

We are pretty new in the Angular and OpenID Connect land, so maybe we are doing things just plain wrong :)

Our IdentityServer (v3 btw) returns a "large" list of claims ("groupSids" and associated roles) from the UserInfoEndpoint 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/756703/29020169-67bb943c-7b61-11e7-9d69-675766a27f1e.png)

The jwt is about >5500 chars.

Now we wanted to implement a proper storage for the auth data, so that we can get the silent renew workflow working, but unfortunately the "authorizationDataIdToken" is too big for the cookie and the browser refuses to save it. 

The library tries to load some important oidc-keys (e.g. "exp") from the JWT token so it seems the complete authorizationDataIdToken is needed.

Have you a suggestion for us? Are we using the userinfo endpoint wrong? We also could "split" the jwt in several cookies (like in the old ASP.NET days) and combine them during runtime, but I'm not sure if this is the way we should go. 
Or just use the HTML5 localStorage? 

We faced a similar problem with our WPF Windows client, but we were using Reference-AccessTokens and using access-tokens & refresh-tokens, but it seems in the Angular world it is different. In the fat client app I only store the accesstoken, the expire-date and the refresh-token and thats it. With them I can get a fresh accesstoken and do a proper logout without the super large JWT token.

Events.RelatedBody:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/756703/29178749-c323335a-7df2-11e7-96a0-fb37c6decc63.png)

Battleship-Grey is not really sexy anymore :)

If you need help and accept PRs please let me know.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ColorPicker: Make Header-Background Configurable" (#1163) at xceedsoftware/wpftoolkit
Events.RelatedBody:
We use the (decade old?) WpfToolkit Version and found a pretty odd styling bug:

It would be nice if we could set the background color for the headers:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/756703/29178489-ff6ee6de-7df1-11e7-9ca0-f3ef2bc9211d.png)

Currently the Background is set to AliceBlue and it is not possible to change it: 
https://github.com/xceedsoftware/wpftoolkit/blob/master/ExtendedWPFToolkitSolution/Src/Xceed.Wpf.Toolkit/ColorPicker/Themes/Generic.xaml#L290

Are you accepting PRs? If yes I could help out :)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Large authorizationDataIdToken (because of roles etc.) & cookie storage" (#56) at damienbod/angular-auth-oidc-client
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi

We are pretty new in the Angular and OpenID Connect land, so maybe we are doing things just plain wrong :)

Our IdentityServer (v3 btw) returns a "large" list of claims ("groupSids" and associated roles) from the UserInfoEndpoint 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/756703/29020169-67bb943c-7b61-11e7-9d69-675766a27f1e.png)

The jwt is about >5500 chars.

Now we wanted to implement a proper storage for the auth data, so that we can get the silent renew workflow working, but unfortunately the "authorizationDataIdToken" is too big for the cookie and the browser refuses to save it. 

The library tries to load some important oidc-keys (e.g. "exp") from the JWT token so it seems the complete authorizationDataIdToken is needed.

Have you a suggestion for us? Are we using the userinfo endpoint wrong? We also could "split" the jwt in several cookies (like in the old ASP.NET days) and combine them during runtime, but I'm not sure if this is the way we should go. 

We faced a similar problem with our WPF Windows client, but we were using Reference-AccessTokens and using access-tokens & refresh-tokens, but it seems in the Angular world it is different. In the fat client app I only store the accesstoken, the expire-date and the refresh-token and thats it. With them I can get a fresh accesstoken and do a proper logout without the super large JWT token.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Redesign] Package edit - submit-button enabled only by focus change" (#4418) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I noticed that the submit button on package edit page is only enabled when I change something *and* change the focus to the next control. It would be better if the trigger would be a keydown event, because it might confuse people like me ;)

Repo:
1. Edit a package
1. Click in the package title input
1. Change the title
1. Try to click on submit

Browser: Chrome 58 on macos.

      "id": 184472409,
      "number": 170,
      "title": "WPF App not starting after IL Repack",
      "user": {
        "login": "robertmuehsig",
        "id": 756703,
        "avatar_url": "https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/756703?v=3",
        "gravatar_id": "",
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig",
        "html_url": "https://github.com/robertmuehsig",
        "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/followers",
        "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/following{/other_user}",
        "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/gists{/gist_id}",
        "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
        "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/subscriptions",
        "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/orgs",
        "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/repos",
        "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/events{/privacy}",
        "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/received_events",
        "type": "User",
        "site_admin": false
      },
      "labels": [],
      "state": "open",
      "locked": false,
      "assignee": null,
      "assignees": [],
      "milestone": null,
      "comments": 13,
      "created_at": "2016-10-21T12:22:09Z",
      "updated_at": "2017-07-11T06:14:33Z",
      "closed_at": null,
      "body": "Hi\r\n\r\nWe tried to use ILRepack to get a single exe of our WPF application, but it didn't work and we are not sure how to fix it - maybe we miss something?\r\n\r\nThe full source of the application can be found here: \r\nhttps://github.com/Sevitec/oneoffixx-connectclient/\r\n\r\nRepo-Steps:\r\n1. Build the application via the build.ps1\r\n2.  Under this path \".\\Windows\\src\\OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp\\bin\\Release\" you should see this: \r\n![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/756703/19598083/1422b6f4-9799-11e6-8ebd-fae21772095a.png)\r\n1. Now we invoke ILRepack like this:\r\n\r\n(C:\\Users\\amacher\\Documents\\GitHub\\oneoffixx-connectclient\\ must be replaced with your clone directory)\r\n\r\n```\r\nILRepack.exe /verbose /log /out:C:\\Users\\amacher\\Documents\\GitHub\\oneoffixx-connectclient\\Windows\\src\\OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp\\bin\\Release\\merged\\Merged.exe C:\\Users\\amacher\\Documents\\GitHub\\oneoffixx-connectclient\\Windows\\src\\OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp\\Release\\Debug\\OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp.exe C:\\Users\\amacher\\Documents\\GitHub\\oneoffixx-connectclient\\Windows\\src\\OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp\\Release\\Debug\\System.Windows.Interactivity.dll C:\\Users\\amacher\\Documents\\GitHub\\oneoffixx-connectclient\\Windows\\src\\OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp\\Release\\Debug\\MahApps.Metro.dll C:\\Users\\amacher\\Documents\\GitHub\\oneoffixx-connectclient\\Windows\\src\\OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp\\Release\\Debug\\Microsoft.Practices.ServiceLocation.dll C:\\Users\\amacher\\Documents\\GitHub\\oneoffixx-connectclient\\Windows\\src\\OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp\\Release\\Debug\\ICSharpCode.AvalonEdit.dll C:\\Users\\amacher\\Documents\\GitHub\\oneoffixx-connectclient\\Windows\\src\\OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp\\Release\\Debug\\FontAwesome.WPF.dll\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe full log output can be found [here](https://github.com/Sevitec/oneoffixx-connectclient/issues/2#issuecomment-255359884)\r\n1. Result is a Merged.exe, but it fails to start.\r\n\r\nThe Windows-Eventlog tells me this:\r\n\r\n```\r\nAnwendung: Merged.exe\r\nFrameworkversion: v4.0.30319\r\nBeschreibung: Der Prozess wurde aufgrund einer unbehandelten Ausnahme beendet.\r\nAusnahmeinformationen: System.IO.FileNotFoundException\r\nbei System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly._nLoad(System.Reflection.AssemblyName, System.String, System.Security.Policy.Evidence, System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly, System.Threading.StackCrawlMark ByRef, IntPtr, Boolean, Boolean, Boolean)\r\nbei System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly.nLoad(System.Reflection.AssemblyName, System.String, System.Security.Policy.Evidence, System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly, System.Threading.StackCrawlMark ByRef, IntPtr, Boolean, Boolean, Boolean)\r\nbei System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly.InternalLoadAssemblyName(System.Reflection.AssemblyName, System.Security.Policy.Evidence, System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly, System.Threading.StackCrawlMark ByRef, IntPtr, Boolean, Boolean, Boolean)\r\nbei System.Reflection.Assembly.Load(System.Reflection.AssemblyName)\r\nbei System.Windows.Navigation.BaseUriHelper.GetLoadedAssembly(System.String, System.String, System.String)\r\nbei MS.Internal.AppModel.ResourceContainer.GetResourceManagerWrapper(System.Uri, System.String ByRef, Boolean ByRef)\r\nbei MS.Internal.AppModel.ResourceContainer.GetPartCore(System.Uri)\r\nbei System.IO.Packaging.Package.GetPartHelper(System.Uri)\r\nbei System.IO.Packaging.Package.GetPart(System.Uri)\r\nbei System.Windows.Application.GetResourceOrContentPart(System.Uri)\r\nbei System.Windows.Application.LoadComponent(System.Object, System.Uri)\r\nbei OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp.App.InitializeComponent()\r\nbei OneOffixx.ConnectClient.WinApp.App.Main()\r\n```\r\n\r\nAny ideas? \r\n\r\nNote that we don't reference ILRepack directly - we saw this in your sample application, but even with the reference it didn't worked.\r\n"
    },
    "comment": {
      "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gluck/il-repack/issues/comments/314341115",
      "html_url": "https://github.com/gluck/il-repack/issues/170#issuecomment-314341115",
      "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gluck/il-repack/issues/170",
      "id": 314341115,
      "user": {
        "login": "robertmuehsig",
        "id": 756703,
        "avatar_url": "https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/756703?v=3",
        "gravatar_id": "",
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig",
        "html_url": "https://github.com/robertmuehsig",
        "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/followers",
        "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/following{/other_user}",
        "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/gists{/gist_id}",
        "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
        "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/subscriptions",
        "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/orgs",
        "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/repos",
        "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/events{/privacy}",
        "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/robertmuehsig/received_events",
        "type": "User",
        "site_admin": false
      },
      "created_at": "2017-07-11T06:14:33Z",
      "updated_at": "2017-07-11T06:14:33Z",
      "body": "This might work. As an alternative: Maybe the ILRepack user could use a special argument so that ILRepack doesn't do the prefixing:\r\n\r\n```\r\nILRepack.exe /verbose /log /out:merged/MetroDemo.exe MetroDemo.exe JetBrains.Annotations.dll MahApps.Metro.dll MahApps.Metro.IconPacks.dll NHotkey.dll NHotkey.Wpf.dll System.Windows.Interactivity.dll /noXamlPrefix:MahApps.Metro.dll  \r\n```\r\n"
    }
  },
  "public": true,
  "created_at": "2017-07-11T06:14:33Z"
}
Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "WPF App not starting after IL Repack" (#170) at gluck/il-repack
Events.RelatedBody:
This might work. As an alternative: Maybe the ILRepack user could use a special argument so that ILRepack doesn't do the prefixing:

```
ILRepack.exe /verbose /log /out:merged/MetroDemo.exe MetroDemo.exe JetBrains.Annotations.dll MahApps.Metro.dll MahApps.Metro.IconPacks.dll NHotkey.dll NHotkey.Wpf.dll System.Windows.Interactivity.dll /noXamlPrefix:MahApps.Metro.dll  
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "display live data in a line chart" (#411) at swimlane/ngx-charts
Events.RelatedBody:
**I'm submitting a ...**  (check one with "x")
```
[x] bug report => search github for a similar issue or PR before submitting
[ ] feature request
[ ] support request => Please do not submit support request here
```

**Current behavior**
If I insert new data point to a line chart, all data points will be animated. 
This will lead to a messy data visualization. 

At first I tryed to simply push new data points, but it looks like change detection does not recognize this.
`
this.multi[0].series.push(data);
`
Rewriting the whole array works but leads to the described behavior. 
`this.multi[0].series.push(data);`
`this.multi = [...this.multi];`


**Expected behavior**
Only the the line for the new data point should be animated. 
Otherwise it would be good to have a option flag, to turn off animations. 

**Reproduction of the problem**
I created a plunkr to show the current behavior:

https://plnkr.co/edit/FXA7r6ISQguTrqAF5YS5

**What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**
I would like to create a chart that shows live data.
Like flot chart does in this example: http://www.flotcharts.org/flot/examples/realtime/index.html

**Environment:**
* **ngx-charts version:** 5.3.1
* **Angular version:** 4.0.0
* **Browser:** [Chrome]
* **Language:** [ TypeScript 2.3.2]

Thank you for your feedback.
